data.title: Bowler takes his dream to the highway
data.meta_description: VICKI PREVOST, Pin Tales \n I recently received the November issue of magazine and, as I usually do when it arrives in the mail, I put everything else aside and quickly scanned through it. \n It didn'tâ€¦
data.text:
VICKI PREVOST, Pin Tales

I recently received the November issue of magazine and, as I usually do when it arrives in the mail, I put everything else aside and quickly scanned through it.

It didn't take me long to find something near and dear to my heart.

On page eight, a story about a 27-year-old man who quit his job in order to visit bowling centers in all 50 states caught my attention.

It brought to mind a dream that I've had for a long, long time and that I've put way in the back of the closet.

I'd like to some day retire from my full-time telecommunications job, purchase an RV and travel to all of the bowling stops on the PBA, PWBA or other bowling tours, take notes, write stories and freelance them to bowling magazines, books and/or newspapers.

I've thought it was silly at times and other times I've thought it's really important to me and I'd like to take off tomorrow.

Reality, and my responsibilities (read bills) makes me keep stuffing the dream back in the closet.

It was really nice for me to read about Mike Walsh. Right now he has no family of his own to support, no mortgage and no real obligations.

He decided to quit his job with a Chicago marketing company and hit the road with his dream of bowling in all 50 states. He will document his experiences for a book, not a bowling book, but a chronicle of the ultimate road trip.

"I've long had a certain affection for The American Bowling Alley," said Walsh, "feeling it was a microcosm of something, though I've never been quite sure what.

"Kind of like the roadside diner, the small town barber shop or the high school basketball game. Each is the same in all of their incarnations, but each is filled with its own idiosyncrasies, its own stories."

He's fulfilling his dream tour before he dives headfirst into real responsibilities as a husband, father and homeowner.

Unfortunately, he has no car. Living in Chicago, he's had no use for one and the insurance, fuel and garaging costs that goes along with owning one.

For his country-wide bowling alley trip, he's using his mother's 1994 Honda Accord. Forty-nine states are accessible by auto, the 50th, Hawaii, is not.

Walsh hasn't mentioned how he's getting there.

Then there's the smallest state, Rhode Island, which has only 10 centers -- will he be able to find one?

Bowlers Journal has promised to keep its readers posted.

I'll keep my readers posted about my dream trip when I'm finally able to take it out of the closet for good, dusted off and headed for the highway.

You can gain some suggestions on learning the basics of bowling by visiting the Web site Bowl.com.

The site has a lot of information like playing rules and instruction class locations.

Another way to gather basic information about bowling is to purchase an instruction book.

Good books are available at your local book store, or if not on the shelf, one may be ordered.

Information on instruction books can be found on the internet also.

Whatever instruction manual you decide to use, make sure you allow yourself plenty of practice.Upcoming events

The Duckpin Junior League will begin on a Saturday this month at Bowlmor Lanes in . For information and to register, call the lanes at (508) 758-6783. Youngsters in grades two-eight are eligible to compete.

The Classie Lassies Match-Point Doubles League is looking for one woman to fill their roster. The league competes on Thursdays at 915 p.m. Call the lanes at (508) 993-1746 for information and to leave a message for Dolly MacMillen, league secretary.

Holiday Lanes in Westport has a Thanksgiving Day 9-Pin No-Tap Tournament Mixed Doubles on Nov. 28 at 730 p.m. There are two divisions (360 and over and 359 and under). Entry fee is $30 per team. Call the lanes at (508) 674-2224 for more information.

November is BVL Month. The Bowlers to Veteran's Link is the Massachusetts Women's Bowling Association annual charity. Cans for collections are at the control desk at each ten pin bowling center throughout the month of November.

An IBA Tournament is Nov. 17 at North Bowl in No. Attleboro. For information, call the lanes at (508) 695-9333.Highlights

Matt Raynor, in the Holiday 4x2 League at Holiday Lanes in Westport, bowled a 299 game that was included in a four-game 980 series and Paul Moser bowled a 1,004 series that included 268 and 258 games.

Shaun Carroll, in the Twilight League at Wonder Bowl, bowled an 11-straight-strike 290 game that was 106 pins over his average.

Greg Martel and Steve Dopart both bowled 11-straight-strike 290 games in the American Men League at Holiday Lanes in Westport last month.

Michael Armberg, in the LaCava Brothers League at AMF Holiday Lanes in Somerset, bowled his first 300 game recently.
